text: ah
hi everyone jack harlow here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for
a review of this new charlotte editiori
and belize pupul record topical dancer
this is a new collaboration between two
artists who hail from belgium and i am
just now learning about them in their
work through this new record here they
have actually been recording and
producing tracks together for a while
now in many ways the quirky and vintage
electro pop that you hear here the
groundwork was laid for it on
charlotte's 2019 ep which was also
produced by belisse and i'm just falling
more and more in love with their sound
and their ideas and their style the more
i listen to this record because
topicaldancer is a record that has a lot
going for it that works in layers
there's loads of clean and crisp
production on this thing not to mention
all the captivating dance grooves
tastefully minimal beats that pull from
a lot of old school strains of very
european techno and electro disco ebm
and synth pop lots of sharp and funny
social commentary the topics of which
vary from track to track all of which is
carried very well by charlotte's
heartening lyrics her wit her humor her
personality it's a record that feels
indebted to the now as well as a
frequent collaborators on the project
soulwax but also a time in music when
artists like kraftwerk as well as laurie
anderson david byrne were expanding the
popular music canon there's something so
sweet and innocent and
endearingly well-meaning about this
record too take the song hey for example
whose very lovely vocal harmonies and
easy going beats weave together
effectively with charlotte's lyrics
about racial and sexual and spiritual
equality stylistically and aesthetically
the whole thing feels like a musical psa
from a 1980s episode of sesame street if
you could like apply to it
some of the equity politics that are
popular online today and i draw that
comparison in the best way possible
because operating from such a fresh and
unsullied place especially as an adult
who is well aware of the horrors of the
world is really difficult because every
year it feels like more and more people
mentally succumb to
the disease of cynicism and if there's a
real point of rebellion on topical
dancer and there are many it's that
cause this record socially has so few
inhibitions and i love it for that and
of course the music itself on this
project too is catchy fun flavorful
there's the song esperanto which
features a lot of primal dance grooves
setting the stage for charlotte's lyrics
about all of the toxic social binaries
that have arisen in the information age
are you polite or political correct or a
cynical which i think is a serious
question to ponder charlotte also
lightens up the vibe of the track a
little bit toward the end with a series
of uh tongue-in-cheek recommendations
that
seemingly are an effort to tell the
listener how to like avoid
microaggressions and stuff like that but
uh the stuff that is
being told to the listener telling them
uh stuff like not ordering a black
americano you know as a coffee instead
say i'll have an african-american please
or don't say only a man is fit for this
job say instead oh well at least you
tried karen just to let you guys know
the level of humor this record is
operating on the song blenda following
this picks up the groove a little bit
with a higher tempo and a sick synth
bass line the track is essentially a
very smart piece of commentary on being
a person who
ancestrally is from a different land a
different culture but the country
they're living in now doesn't identify
them as as being a part of the community
they exist in i also love the way she
poses so cluelessly in a hilarious way
to siri the question of where do i
belong and how long is the road there
the group vocal breakdown in french on
the track is spectacular too with all
the hand drums later in the track list
it hit me is one of the most interesting
explorations of sexuality i've heard on
any lp really coming to terms with your
sexuality and sexual attraction at a
very young age with charlotte describing
with pitched vocals to make it sound
like she is much younger telling a story
where she's 13 they're like wolf

describing a group of guys like oggling

course there is the point where she says

immediately after that realization is

somehow recaptures the classic german

womanhood it is one of the lengthier

some
nasally falsetto type highs that feel

once
